## Descriptions

This issue intends to integrate testing ability into our repo as early as possible to prevent future conflict and satisfy the code coverage requirements of this project.

We currently looking at [Jest](https://jestjs.io/) and [Cypres](https://www.cypress.io/). Read more about how to set them up [here](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/testing/cypress) and [here](https://nextjs.org/docs/app/building-your-application/testing/jest)

## Requirements 

- [ ] Install the compatibility version of the two into our repo
- [ ] Create config and best practices for Nextjs framework
- [ ] Have a sample test of each (a dummy one), they would be a template for future testing issues.
- [ ] Write documentation of how to run them respectively (code commenting or in README)

## (Optional) 

We could look into an online website to do a scan on our repo (this is for future issues but look into them doesn't hurt now)

Two that I know include: 

+ [codecov](https://about.codecov.io/)
+ [codefactor](https://www.codefactor.io/)

## Further comments

TBD.

This is a fairly simple task and you can follow the tutorial [here](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HEX6qKCMdbM).

## Description

We will use Clerk as discussed in our previous meetings as our authentication provider. It will provide both security and options to have multiple SSOs. The service can be found [here](https://clerk.com/)

The guide for installation can be found [here](https://clerk-docs-git-prettier-fixes.clerkpreview.com/quickstarts/nextjs/app-router)

## Requirements

- [ ] Sign up for an account in Clerk (Free tier) and it's going to be our main account on the platform.
- [ ] Install clerk and necessary dependencies into our repo
- [ ] Follow the guide, and include the key to env, make sure you share it with everyone
- [ ] Have the SignIn and SignUp components ready.
- [ ] Do any documentation about this third-party service you found is needed for the team.
- [ ] You don't have to do the design, just a simple SSO to Google is fine

## Further comments

The guide said it's still in beta for the app router (what we have) so you might need to watch out for potential issues but we got it working before so it really, really, really unlikely we run into a `lajsk???fhakcb%@nsa!#dljk?` bug

Do look at one of my previous repo for reference if needed

## Description

This issue aims to update README with the steps needed to set up the repo for an individual development environment. Also, make a step-by-step guide of how we will branch out and work on issues that got assigned. The guide also showcases our `issues tracker` a.k.a `issue board` and what they can do to organize our project. In addition, it also includes the most common git commands we will use to avoid merge conflict.

## Requirements

- [ ] Update README 
- [ ] Make the workflow
- [ ] Finalized common git commands
- [ ] And standardize with our GitHub issue such as naming convention 

## (Optional) git `commit message` convention

On a personal note: not strictly required to everyone, but something I like to do is have some prefix to my commit that indicates what just happened. I will include it but everyone is free to have their commit messages to their like.

## Further comments

TBD.

## Description

This is the start of our backend, we will use MySQL as our database, and Prisma as our ORM. This is pretty much the combo for personal projects (as they are free). 

The reason why we use Prisma to control our schema is due to our usage of TypeScript (type-safe db is all we care about). This reduces the complexity of the backend and lowers the development overhead.

Service: [PlanetScale](https://planetscale.com/)
Service: [Prisma](https://www.prisma.io/)


## Requirements

- [x] Create a PlanetScale account and create a db for our project
- [x] Integrate Prisma as the ORM right after the creation of the DB instance
- [x] Since PlanetScale is MySQL so is a pain when we try to abstract this through Prisma, the setup will be slightly different (updated syntax or migration with db), so don't follow the usual installation 100%, read more [here](https://www.prisma.io/docs/orm/overview/databases/planetscale)
- [x] Documentation of what commands we will need to use to:
- [x] Sync our schema to db, as well as able to run the Prisma client (<-- this is important!)
- [x] Have some basic Prisma schema, for now, we haven't defined our db to the fullest.

## (Optional) 

- [x] Having more than 1 db instance is nice, free tier allows us to do 2? This benefits us if we want one for testing, and one for production (production is our deployment, and we don't want to show unhinged testing on it)
- [x] Have Mockup data or create mockup data for testing (this is for future issues, discard if needed)

## Further Comments

You can look at one of my repos for reference, as this is what I used before :DDDD

## Description

In this issue, we work on a design system for our web app, for both website and mobile phone viewport using Figma, this will help us establish consistency and development-friendliness throughout our project. 

## Requirements

Outline the specific objectives and requirements needed to finish the issue. Clearly state what success looks like for this issue.

- [ ] Design a color scheme, and typography (fonts) for our web app
- [ ] An intuitive navigation system across all pages/screens
- [ ] Incorporate elements of gamification in the design, such as badges and streaks, to visually engage users and encourage consistent app usage.
- [ ] Doable, adaptable to both web and mobile viewports
- [ ] Include reference in the Figma design, as well as svg(s), styles that we will use.

## (Optional)

- Start with a mobile-first design approach to ensure the app's core features are optimized for smaller screens, then scale up to accommodate larger web interfaces.

Note on testing:

In order to test the component, there are two main cases based on retrieved data using userID in `apps/expo/src/app/spotify/index.tsx`.

General testing will go something along these lines:

1) Make sure a SpotifyData row exists for the user you will be querying.
2) Use that user's ID to query the SpotifyData using the API (just update the ID field in `apps/expo/src/app/spotify/index.tsx` from above.
3) Depending on if the row itself had isPlaying as false or true, one of two things will happen:
3a) If it's false, then the third screenshot should show.
3b) Otherwise something similar to the first two screenshots will show.

To check what shows up, navigate to "Screens" and click on "Spotify" within the mobile app itself.
Results should be rendered there.

performed_via_github_app.description:
Codecov provides highly integrated tools to group, merge, archive and compare coverage reports. Whether your team is comparing changes in a pull request or reviewing a single commit, Codecov will improve the code review workflow and quality.

## Code coverage done right.

1. Upload coverage reports from your CI builds.
2. Codecov merges all builds and languages into one beautiful coherent report.
3. Get commit statuses, pull request comments and coverage overlay via our browser extension.

When Codecov merges your uploads it keeps track of the CI provider (inc. build details) and user specified context, e.g. `#unittest` ~ `#smoketest` or `#oldcode` ~ `#newcode`. You can track the `#unittest` coverage independently of other groups. [Learn more here](
http://docs.codecov.io/docs/flags)

Through **Codecov's Browser Extension** reports overlay directly in GitHub UI to assist in code review in [Chrome](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/codecov/gedikamndpbemklijjkncpnolildpbgo) or Firefox (https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/codecov/)

*Highly detailed* **pull request comments** and *customizable* **commit statuses** will improve your team's workflow and code coverage incrementally.

**File backed configuration** all through the `codecov.yml`. 

## FAQ

For the most recent iteration of this PR, here is some information: 1. I have simplified some of the styling by using const variables, viewStyles and textStyles, to make the main code easier to read. 2. I tried to use TailwindCSS, but the styling was not coming out like I wanted (I wanted to maintain the original page appearance). 3. performed_via_github_app.name: Codecov
performed_via_github_app.description:
Codecov provides highly integrated tools to group, merge, archive and compare coverage reports. Whether your team is comparing changes in a pull request or reviewing a single commit, Codecov will improve the code review workflow and quality.

## Code coverage done right.

1. Upload coverage reports from your CI builds.
2. Codecov merges all builds and languages into one beautiful coherent report.
3. Get commit statuses, pull request comments and coverage overlay via our browser extension.

When Codecov merges your uploads it keeps track of the CI provider (inc. build details) and user specified context, e.g. `#unittest` ~ `#smoketest` or `#oldcode` ~ `#newcode`. You can track the `#unittest` coverage independently of other groups. [Learn more here](
http://docs.codecov.io/docs/flags)

Through **Codecov's Browser Extension** reports overlay directly in GitHub UI to assist in code review in [Chrome](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/codecov/gedikamndpbemklijjkncpnolildpbgo) or Firefox (https://addons.mozilla.org/en-US/firefox/addon/codecov/)

*Highly detailed* **pull request comments** and *customizable* **commit statuses** will improve your team's workflow and code coverage incrementally.

**File backed configuration** all through the `codecov.yml`. 

## FAQ
- Do you **merge multiple uploads** to the same commit? **Yes**
- Do you **support multiple languages** in the same project? **Yes**
- Can you **group coverage reports** by project and/or test type? **Yes**
- How does **pricing** work? Only paid users can view reports and post statuses/comments.
